title: Four Perspectives on the Great Disintermediation Thesis

perspectives.name: Media Executive
perspectives.role: CEO of legacy media company, 25 years in news and publishing
perspectives.initial_position: I've lived through the last 20 years of disintermediation and I can tell you: the thesis is correct about the direction and wrong about the destination. Yes, technology removes gatekeepers. But it doesn't remove the need for gatekeeping. What happens when you eliminate editorial judgment? You get misinformation, conspiracy theories, and algorithmic radicalization. We destroyed the village and now everyone is surprised there are wolves. My industry failed to adapt quickly enough, but the replacement—algorithmic content distribution with no accountability—is demonstrably worse for society. The question isn't whether disintermediation happens. It's whether the result is liberation or chaos.
key_threats: Our advertising revenue model was built for attention scarcity. When there were 3 networks and 1 local newspaper, we controlled attention and charged accordingly. Now attention is infinite and distributed. Digital advertising revenue per reader is 10-20% of print equivalents. The entire business model of quality journalism is collapsing, and no one has found a sustainable replacement at scale.

Trust erosion feeds on itself. Edelman shows institutional media trust at historic lows. But the less people trust us, the more they turn to unvetted sources, which makes them less informed, which makes them trust institutions less. It's a death spiral. AI-generated content accelerates this—when anyone can produce professional-looking 'news,' the concept of authoritative reporting dissolves.

Our best talent is leaving for creator economy platforms. A star reporter with 100K Twitter followers can make more on Substack than we pay them. They take the audience with them. We're left with the overhead of a newsroom, the brand liability of a media company, and the revenue of a lifestyle blog.
key_moves: Pivot from mass media to niche authority. We can't compete with TikTok for attention. We CAN be the authoritative source for specific domains where trust and accuracy matter: financial markets, healthcare policy, legal analysis. Smaller audience, higher willingness to pay.

Build direct subscriber relationships and eliminate advertising dependency. The New York Times model (10M+ subscribers) shows it's possible at scale. Most publishers gave up too early and defaulted to SEO-driven ad revenue. That's a race to the bottom. Premium content behind a paywall is the only sustainable model.

Use AI to reduce production costs, not to generate content. AI can automate research, data analysis, distribution optimization, and personalization. Use the savings to invest in the human judgment and investigation that AI can't replicate. Become more human by being better at technology.
blind_spots: I keep assuming the solution is 'better journalism' because that's what I know. But maybe the market has spoken: most people don't want journalism in the traditional sense. They want entertainment, community, and narrative—and platforms deliver those better than newsrooms. My industry's problem might not be disintermediation but irrelevance.

The 'reintermediation' scenario deserves more weight. Google, Apple, and Meta control distribution more absolutely than any media company ever did. The printing press disintermediated monasteries, but the publishing houses that followed were powerful gatekeepers too. We might be in the chaotic middle between old gatekeepers dying and new ones consolidating.
perspectives.revised_position: The thesis is correct that technology is removing institutional gatekeeping power. But the story it's telling—liberation from gatekeepers—is incomplete. What's actually happening is a transfer of gatekeeping power from institutions with editorial judgment to platforms with algorithmic optimization. The algorithms don't care about truth, accuracy, or public interest—they optimize for engagement. The result isn't disintermediation; it's reintermediation by entities with fundamentally different incentives. My revised view: the next 10 years will see a backlash as the consequences of algorithmic gatekeeping become undeniable. Quality media brands that survive the current crisis will benefit from a flight to credibility—not mass market, but premium positioning. The business model is smaller, more focused, and more sustainable than what we had. But we have to survive the next 5 years to get there.

perspectives.name: Creator Economy Founder
perspectives.role: Built a creator platform to 5M users, former journalist turned entrepreneur
perspectives.initial_position: The thesis is the operating manual for my business. Every institution that controlled access—media companies, publishers, record labels, talent agencies, universities—is being unbundled by individuals with tools and distribution. The pattern is always the same: first the institution's distribution monopoly breaks, then its talent leaves, then its brand erodes, then it either adapts or dies. We're seeing this play out across every knowledge and creative industry simultaneously. AI is the final accelerant: it gives every individual the production capabilities that used to require institutional infrastructure.
key_threats: The 'two guys and a tool' pattern is accelerating. A solo creator with AI tools can produce content, analyze data, design products, and serve clients that used to require teams of 20+. The productivity multiplier isn't 2x—it's 10-50x for certain types of work. Every institution competing against AI-augmented individuals is structurally disadvantaged.

Platform economics favor creators, not institutions. Instagram, YouTube, TikTok, Substack—the distribution platforms are designed for individuals, not organizations. Algorithmic distribution rewards personality, authenticity, and consistency—exactly what individuals do better than institutions.

The trust shift is generational and irreversible. Gen Z doesn't trust the New York Times or Goldman Sachs. They trust individual creators and influencers they follow. This isn't a temporary social media fad—it's a permanent rewiring of how information authority works. The institution-as-authority model is dying with the generation that grew up with it.
key_moves: Build tools that amplify individual creators' capabilities. The business isn't in creating content—it's in enabling millions of creators to produce at institutional quality. AI writing assistants, design tools, analytics platforms, monetization infrastructure—the picks-and-shovels of disintermediation.

Create network effects around creator communities. Individual creators are vulnerable; creator networks with shared resources, cross-promotion, and collective bargaining power are defensible. Think Hollywood studios but for creators—providing infrastructure without controlling the talent.

Target regulated industries where disintermediation is just beginning: legal services, financial advice, healthcare information. These are protected by licensing, liability, and regulation—but the pressure is building. When it breaks, the opportunity is enormous.
blind_spots: I'm romanticizing the creator economy. The reality: 97% of creators make less than minimum wage. Power law distribution means a few mega-creators capture most of the value while millions struggle. Platform algorithms are as arbitrary as any institutional gatekeeper—one algorithm change can destroy a creator's livelihood overnight.

Quality control is genuinely harder without institutions. When everyone can publish, the signal-to-noise ratio plummets. My platform's biggest challenge isn't distribution—it's helping users find quality in an ocean of content. Institutions solved this through editorial judgment. We're solving it through algorithms and crowd voting. I'm not sure our solution is better.
perspectives.revised_position: The disintermediation thesis is the defining trend of the next decade, but I'm more nuanced about the destination. The pure 'institutions die, individuals win' narrative is too simple. The emerging model is a hybrid: individuals with institutional-quality tools, organized in loose networks, operating on platforms that provide distribution. The institutions that survive will be those that function as platforms for talent rather than controllers of talent. The ones that die will be those that try to maintain gatekeeping power with outdated infrastructure. My business strategy: build the infrastructure layer that enables this hybrid model. Not a media company, not a tech platform, but the connective tissue that lets individual talent operate at institutional scale.

perspectives.name: Institutional Investor
perspectives.role: CIO of $20B endowment, allocates across public and private markets
perspectives.initial_position: This thesis is intellectually compelling but investably imprecise. 'Technology removes gatekeepers' has been true since Gutenberg. The question for my portfolio is: who captures the value when the current gatekeepers fall? The Reformation didn't make everyone rich—it made the printing press operators and the new Protestant institutions wealthy. Similarly, disintermediation doesn't distribute value equally. It concentrates it in platforms and the small number of individuals who master them. My job is to find the next concentration of value, not celebrate the distribution of it.
key_threats: The public market expression of this thesis is mostly priced in. Meta, Google, Amazon—the platform gatekeepers—already trade at valuations that reflect their gatekeeping power. The private market opportunity is in the tools and infrastructure that enable individual competitors, but these are mostly unprofitable, venture-stage, and risky. The risk-adjusted return on the 'long disintermediation' trade isn't as attractive as the thesis makes it sound.

Regulatory risk is the wild card. If governments decide that platform power is as dangerous as institutional power (which the thesis implies with 'reintermediation'), antitrust action, data regulation, and platform liability could dramatically change the value distribution. The EU is already moving in this direction. The US might follow.

The thesis assumes disintermediation is permanent. But history shows cycles of intermediation and disintermediation. The printing press disrupted monasteries but created publishing houses. The internet disrupted publishers but created platforms. AI might disrupt platforms but create... what? The next intermediary isn't visible yet, but it's coming.
key_moves: Allocate to private markets focused on 'picks and shovels' for creators: AI tools, monetization infrastructure, community platforms, and creator-focused financial services. The value capture in disintermediation is in enabling rather than performing.

Short legacy media and professional services firms that can't adapt. Specific targets: companies with high fixed costs, talent-dependent business models, and declining pricing power. These are the institutions the thesis identifies as most vulnerable.

Long the platform layer—but hedge for regulatory intervention. Own Google, Meta, Apple with protective puts. The thesis says platforms are the new gatekeepers. If that's true, they're either enormously valuable (capture the gatekeeping premium) or enormously regulated (governments won't tolerate private gatekeeping power indefinitely). Position for the former, hedge for the latter.
blind_spots: My framework is biased toward concentration because that's what creates investable opportunities. But this thesis might describe a genuinely distributed outcome where value is widely shared and no single entity captures disproportionate returns. In that world, the investment strategy isn't 'find the winner'—it's 'own the index of enablers' and accept market returns. That's unsatisfying for an active investor but might be reality.

I'm thinking about this through financial markets. But the biggest impact of disintermediation might be political and social—erosion of institutional trust, rise of populism, collapse of shared narratives. These aren't directly investable but they create regime risk that my portfolio models don't capture.
perspectives.revised_position: The thesis is correct as a secular trend. My investment strategy: 15% allocation to 'disintermediation enablers' in private markets (creator tools, AI infrastructure, alternative credentialing), funded by reducing allocation to legacy media and traditional professional services. In public markets, maintain platform exposure with regulatory hedges. The key portfolio insight: disintermediation is deflationary for labor-intensive knowledge work and inflationary for human attention and authentic expertise. Position long the scarce resource (genuine expertise, trusted voices) and short the commodity (institutional overhead, gatekeeping infrastructure). Timeline: this is a 10-20 year structural shift, not a 3-year trade. Size positions accordingly.

perspectives.name: Platform Entrepreneur
perspectives.role: Co-founder of $2B vertical SaaS platform that replaced institutional workflows
perspectives.initial_position: I've built my career disintermediating a specific industry: legal services. Our platform lets solo practitioners and small firms deliver work that used to require AmLaw 100 infrastructure—document automation, AI research, practice management, client portals. We took a $400B industry controlled by partnerships and gave the tools to individuals. Revenue per lawyer on our platform is 3x what associates make at big firms, because we eliminated the 70% overhead that partnerships extract. This thesis is my business plan, and it works across every professional services vertical.
key_threats: Professional licensing is the last moat for institutional knowledge work. You need a law degree to practice law, a medical degree to practice medicine, a CPA to audit. These licensing requirements were designed to ensure quality but function as gatekeeping mechanisms that protect incumbents. AI challenges this: if an AI can pass the bar exam, why does a human need to? The regulatory battle over AI in licensed professions will determine the pace of disintermediation.

My platform reduces the cost of legal work by 60%. That's not optimization—it's structural disruption. A solo practitioner with our tools and AI can handle a caseload that used to require a 5-person team. Scale that across law, accounting, consulting, and healthcare administration—you're looking at millions of knowledge work jobs that exist because institutional overhead requires them, not because clients need them.

The education pipeline is broken for the new model. Law schools, business schools, and medical schools train people to work in institutional settings. They don't train Knowledge Programmers. The gap between what institutions produce and what the market needs is widening. The first professional school that trains for AI-augmented individual practice will have 10x the placement rate and graduate salary.
key_moves: Expand the platform to adjacent professional services: accounting, HR consulting, management consulting, financial advisory. The pattern is identical: institutional overhead is 60-70% of revenue, tools can replace most of it, and the individual practitioner keeps the client relationship plus the margin.

Build the 'professional marketplace'—connecting clients directly with AI-augmented practitioners, bypassing firm overhead. Like Uber for professional services, but with quality controls, insurance, and platform trust. The institutional brand becomes the platform brand.

Invest in regulatory strategy. Every industry we enter will have incumbents using regulation to slow disintermediation. We need policy teams, lobbying capability, and strategic litigation capacity. This isn't just a technology play—it's a regulatory play. First mover in regulatory positioning wins the market.
blind_spots: I'm solving for cost efficiency, but some institutional functions can't be unbundled. Complex litigation requires teams. Audit opinions carry institutional liability. Brain surgery needs hospital infrastructure. The thesis applies most cleanly to routine professional work and least to complex, high-stakes work. I might be building for the 70% that commoditizes while the 30% that requires institutions becomes more valuable.

Platform dependency is real for my users. Solo practitioners on my platform are more productive but also more dependent. If I raise prices, change terms, or deprecate features, they have no fallback. I'm disintermediating law firms and potentially becoming a more powerful intermediary. The Media Executive's point about reintermediation applies directly to what I'm building.
perspectives.revised_position: I'm doubling down on the disintermediation thesis with more aggressive expansion. Adding 3 new professional verticals (accounting, HR consulting, financial planning) in the next 18 months. Each follows the same playbook: identify the institutional overhead, build tools that let individuals deliver equivalent work, and capture platform economics. The thesis is my competitive strategy. But I'm also more honest about the endgame: I'm not eliminating gatekeepers, I'm becoming one. The difference is that my gatekeeping creates more value for practitioners (they keep 90% vs. 30% at traditional firms) and more value for clients (60% cost reduction). That's a defensible form of intermediation—the market accepts it because everyone except the old gatekeepers is better off.

consensus: Institutional gatekeeping power is structurally declining across media, professional services, finance, and education—this is a multi-decade, irreversible trend
AI is the final accelerant: it gives individuals production capabilities that previously required institutional infrastructure
The value shift isn't from institutions to chaos—it's from institutions to platforms and AI-augmented individuals operating on those platforms
Professional licensing is the last structural defense for institutional knowledge work, and it's being challenged
Institutional overhead (60-70% of professional services revenue) is the specific target of disintermediation
disagreements: Destination: Media Executive sees reintermediation by platforms as equally dangerous; Creator Economy Founder sees genuine individual empowerment; Platform Entrepreneur acknowledges becoming a new gatekeeper but a better one

Quality: Media Executive argues institutional gatekeeping provided quality control; Creator Economy Founder says crowd-sourced quality is sufficient; Institutional Investor sees quality as a scarce resource that commands premium pricing

Value capture: Institutional Investor says value concentrates in platforms; Platform Entrepreneur says practitioners capture more value; Creator Economy Founder says tools companies capture value; all three might be correct for different market segments

Regulation: Platform Entrepreneur sees regulation as a competitive moat to navigate; Institutional Investor sees it as the main risk to platform value; Media Executive hopes regulation will restore institutional relevance
synthesis.key_insight: The most revealing tension in this debate: every participant is simultaneously a disintermediate and a re-intermediator. The Creator Economy Founder is building a platform. The Platform Entrepreneur is replacing law firms with a new gatekeeper. Even the Media Executive's survival strategy (niche authority) is a form of re-intermediation around expertise. This suggests the thesis is correct about the WHAT (institutional power declining) but incomplete about the WHO (new intermediaries, not pure disintermediation). The Reformation didn't eliminate religious authority—it redistributed it from one institution to many. The Great Disintermediation isn't eliminating gatekeeping—it's fragmenting it across platforms, tools, and individuals in ways that create more competitive markets but don't create the fully disintermediated utopia the thesis implies.
